results.description:
Come one, come all for a Holiday season Dance Walk! Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop--everybody listens to their own music. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. For inspiration, check out:

www.24hoursofhappy.com

results.description:
LEADER: Karen Rose ([masked] or[masked])

RATING: B 5/7 B

Must e-mail or call to register. Meet 10AM at Ramapo Reservation Parking Lot on Rt 202.Weather conditions will determine route. Rain cancels. TC North Jersey map 115.

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

results.description:
Join us on Saturday, December 12, 2015 at 10:00 a.m. to hear Jacob M. Appel, MD, JD, a psychiatrist and professional bioethicist, speak on the topic of Free Market In Organs: The Case For Decriminalization. The event will take place in the Library of the Queens Pride House located at[masked]th Avenue, Suite 206, Jackson Heights, New York 11372. 

ADMISSION FEE: $3.00 for Members; $5.00 for Non-Members 

If you are driving, arrive early to look for free street parking. There are also many 2-hour Muni-Meter spots and a nearby parking lot.

If you are coming by subway, use the IRT "7" Flushing Line and exit at 74th Street/Broadway. You can also use the IND "E", "F" or "R" Queens Blvd. Lines and exit at the Jackson Heights/Roosevelt Avenue stop.

If you get lost, call Dr. Tom Stevens on his cell phone at[masked]-7075.

================

Jacob M. Appel, MD, JD, is a psychiatrist and professional bioethicist who writes about issues at the nexus of law, medicine, and morality. Dr. Appel taught bioethics for many years at Brown University  and later at NYU and Columbia, before joining the faculty at Mount Sinai.  He has been a regular ethics columnist at the Huffington Post, Opposing Views and Education Update, and has contributed Op-Eds and commentary to dozens of national and regional newspapers including The New York Times, New York Post, New York Daily News, Chicago Tribune, Detroit Free Press, San Francisco Chronicle and Providence Journal.  He publishes regularly in such journals as Hastings Center Report, The Cambridge Quarterly of Healthcare Ethics,Bulletin of the History of Medicine, The Journal of Law, Medicine and Ethics, The Journal of Medical Ethics, The Journal of Bioethical Inquiry and numerous law reviews.  His essays, which have been shortlisted for Best American Essays on multiple occasions, were recently collected in the volume, Phoning Home (University of South Carolina Press, 2014)  His seventh volume of fiction, a collection of short stories, was published by Black Lawrence Press in July 2015.

Check out the links below for more information.

Grand Central Station Holiday Fair
If you love the New York holiday shopping experience, but would rather stay warm while doing it, then the Grand Central Holiday Fair is for you. Located in the Terminal’s historic Vanderbilt Hall, browse through 76 vendors with an array of artisans selling unique crafts, jewelry, clothing, home furnishings, childrens gifts and more

www.grandcentralterminal.com

Bryant Park Holiday Village
Perfect for everything on your wish list, head to Bryant Park for a unique holiday shopping experience. Venture to the ice skating rink or show off your singing voice at the Columbia Freezer Tour. Here, visitors can sing karaoke with friends in a 7 foot freezer while testing out a Columbia Omni-Heat jacket. Don’t worry, there’s always hot chocolate to be found afterward to warm up. results.description:
COME JOIN US FOR A SHORT AND EASY HIKE TO THE RED HILL FIRE TOWER. WE ARE KEEPING IT SIMPLE SO THAT WE MAY GET BACK IN TIME FOR AN EVENING EVENT. CURRENTLY THIS IS THE ONLY FIRE TOWER IN THE CATSKILLS THAT I HAVEN'T BEEN TO!


PLEASE WEAR BRIGHT COLORS SO THAT YOU ARE VISIBLE TO HUNTERS SHOULD WE ENCOUNTER ANY.

This is one of the easy hikes in the Catskill Mountains. It is not very steep and nor is it long. And, there is a nice place on top to have a picnic, and you have great views from the fire tower.

The hike starts off from the DEC parking lot. You have to cross a small stream not far from the parking lot. During high water, it might be more challenging to cross the stream. From there the trail wraps around the mountain, and the trail is easy to hike. When you get near the top, there is a small trail off to the right. This small trail will take you to a spring. After the Spring, you will go up a couple small switchbacks, and then the trail will level off. Once you reach the top, there is a nice grassy area with a Ranger Station. There are also picnic tables. The Red Hill Fire Tower will provide you with some nice views.

http://catskillmountaineer.com/SD-redhill.html

WE WILL MEET AT the Red Hill Fire Tower Trailhead (Old Dinch Rd, Grahamsville, NY)


DISTANCE: Approximately 3 miles

HIKING PACE: up to 1-2 mph


ESTIMATED HIKE TIME: 2-3 hours

DIFFICULTY: Easy


CURRENT WEATHER FORECAST: Cloudy with a high of 53 degrees


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support


• A Small Pack


• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.

• Windbreaker, warm layers, hat, gloves, etc.

• Gaiters


• Hiking Poles




RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Catskills Trails Map Set

Catskill Hiking maximum group size limitations.

• A group size limit of 12 people for day hiking off-trail or in wilderness areas is in place. Any group larger than 12 must split up (by no less than 1 mile) into smaller, self-sufficient groups that satisfy the size requirement. These groups shall not congregate into one large group at trail junctions, rest stops, lunch breaks, etc.

• In all other areas of the Catskills a group size limit of 20 is in place. Groups larger than 20 must split up (by no less than 1 mile) into smaller, self-sufficient groups that satisfy the size requirement. These groups shall not congregate into one large group at trail junctions, rest stops, lunch breaks, etc.


 NYC HIKING & OUTDOOR ADVENTURE GROUP LEGAL DISCLAIMER
Waiver of liability

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

The NYC Hiking & Outdoor Adventure Group does not provide liability insurance for the protection of individuals who may participate in any of the events planned by the Organizer or Assistant Organizers.

This release extends and applies to, and also covers and includes, all unknown, unforeseen, unanticipated and unsuspected injuries, damages, loss and liability.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. By signing up for this group or event you understand that you are attending all events AT YOUR OWN RISK. Organizers and Assistant Organizers of this group are just that, we organize the events and hike together as friends. There are no leaders on these hikes, you are your own leader- This is YOUR hike.

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Join us for a full Saturday of social Wikipedia editing at the first ever Art & Law edit-a-thon (drop-in any time!), organized by the Art & Law Program and The Law Office of Sergio Muñoz Sarmiento.


During this time we will create, update, and improve Wikipedia articles pertaining to art & law, including art and culture law, authentication, contracts, certificates of authenticity, The Artist's Reserved Rights Transfer and Sale Agreement, appropriation art, deaccessioning, "fair use" principles, copyright, copyleft, moral rights and the 1990 Visual Artists Rights Act, freedom of expression, property law, right of publicity and right of privacy, public art, trademarks, and legal cases, including Cariou v. Prince, Mass MoCA v. Büchel, Serra v. U.S. General Services Administration, Rogers v. Koons, Blanch v. Koons, Greenberg Gallery v. Bauman, and Kelley v. Chicago Park District.


The following artists and how their practices relate to law are also in need of articles, updates and improvements: Ai Weiwei, Michael Asher, Christoph Buchel, Lygia Clark, Dan Flavin, Andrea Fraser, Felix Gonzalez-Torres, Hans Haacke, David Hammons, Donald Judd, Mary Kelly, Sherrie Levine, Santiago Sierra, Elaine Sturtevant, and of course, many more! 


The following art movements and how they relate to law and language are also in need of articles, updates and improvements. They include, Pop Art, Fluxus, Conceptual Art, Institutional Critique, The Pictures Generation, and Feminist Art. 

And don’t forget to write home to mom and pop. As an added bonus, we’ll have stamped-envelopes and paper available so you can write home to mom and dad and say “hi,” the old fashioned way! 


Everyone is welcome to attend: artists, art historians, architects, art critics, art students, lawyers, law students, and regardless of experience. We are happy to teach you the basics of editing Wikipedia. The public is welcome to this event, and The Art & Law Program will provide light snacks and refreshments. 


Working online at the intersection of WikiProject Law, Wikiproject Visual Arts, and also WikiProject Open! 


Page on Wikipedia:


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/NYC/Art_&_Law


Please sign up by December 10, and be prepared to bring a photo ID with you for the university front desk.

Registration URL: https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/6027612174585232898

On December 12th, join Golden Gate University Adjunct Professor Roman Bogomazov for a 3-hour complimentary webinar in which you will learn how to screen for and trade winning stocks using the timeless market principles of Richard D. Wyckoff. During this session, Roman and the webinar participants will interactively analyze and paper-trade a stock campaign as the chart develops over time, an approach he uses to teach his students how to read and profit from market action. This case study will illustrate how to:

• Analyze market structure through a Wyckoff lens, identifying key events such as springs and upthrusts
• Filter potential trade candidates through analysis of:
o The overall market trend
o Relative and comparative strength
o Industry and peer groups
• Analyze price bar volume and spread
• Read supply and demand structural signatures
• Enter high reward-to-risk trades based on market structure
• Manage the trade

Richard Wyckoff is considered one of the giants of technical analysis, whose principles of reading the market are based only on evaluation of price, volume and time – no indicators needed! Many professional and institutional traders’ stock campaigns rely on these principles, which apply to both swing trading and long-term investing. Learn how you can join them and profit!

Sign up now for this fun session, which will be packed with analytical and trading insights that you can use immediately!

When: December 12, 2015; 11:00am – 2:00 p.m. EST

Register for this free event by clicking on the link below:
https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/6027612174585232898
results.name: Holiday Special: How to Select and Trade Winning Stocks Using the Wyckoff Method

results.description:
Oh, the weather outside is frightful
But the fire is so delightful
And since we've no place to go
Let....us go to museums.

NYC has tons of museums, and being that the temperature is dropping we need places that are warm. One such places are museums. From history, to nature, to science, paintings more.

First stop: The American Museum of Natural History.

This iconic place has tons, hundreds of tons of exhibitions from bones of dinosaurs and today's animals, to stuffed animals, human history like evolution and civilizations, bugs exhibitions such as butterflies and spiders, from the depth of the earth to about space. We will spend hours all day in there just exploring.

Admissions:

This can be talked about when we all meet. Just want to remind all that IT IS ALLOT TO SEE. We will not see it all. General admission: $22
General admission +1: $27 (plus one means one special exhibition we can see. ex: the butterflies, spiders, planetarium, etc).
Super Savor admission: $35, all exhibitions are included such as the butterflies, planetarium, spiders, etc.

We will meet at the Central Park West Facade of the building where the President Theodore Roosevelt statue is. Any questions, pm me or comment. See ya there
(Also pleas hold the Night At The Museum references. The outside of the museum was filmed but not the inside. No exhibitions comes to life at night. The movie is fiction.)
results.name: Bronies Visit Museum #1

results.description:
I will present short, intuitive, middle school level math puzzles and riddles:

- why tiny black holes are bright and big ones dim.

- a paradox (to be resolved at the meeting): how a  '70S NASA rocket can escape from a galactic BH.

- an amazingly simple blueprint for a death star that quite literally smashes the holographic principle to oblivion.


- why space must be finite and time always infinite; hint: (mis?)use of the holographic principle and Bohr's view of reality.


- another paradox (to be resolved at the meeting): how the accelerating expansion of the universe effectively shrinks the universe; hint: same as above.

On a more solid footing Barry will derive the FRW model (the Standard Model of modern cosmology) of the expanding universe, and then discuss the presence of cosmological horizons as well as the similarities between these horizons and black hole horizons. 


Cheers,

Moshe Rozenblit
results.name: Holiday special: puzzles  of quantum cosmology and the expanding universe

results.description:
The Ten Perfections are important mind/body qualities or strengths that we can cultivate in any life situation and on the cushion.  When we make these Perfections our priority in life, they support us on our journey toward awake awareness.      

The Ten Perfections or qualities of mind are:

Generosity (Giving)
Virtue (Morality/Ethics)
Renunciation (Letting go of obstacles to awakening)
Wisdom (Discernment)
Energy (Effort)
Patience (Endurance)
Truthfulness
Determination/Resolution
Loving Kindness/Goodwill
Equanimity (Impartiality and balance)

The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.


Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: The Ten Perfections - Patience

“Even after 28 years of experience, I returned a second time to gain from Eric's wealth of knowledge. His advice on purchasing lighting equipment alone paid for the seminar twice!" – Paul Papier, Commercial Photographer, TV Producer 

Enjoyed our Intensive Lighting Workshop? Thirsty for more knowledge? Well then you’re in for a treat. On December 12th and 13th we will be hosting a special edition ADVANCED Lighting Workshop that takes the next step in all areas of film lighting. If you haven’t taken our Intensive Workshop, don’t worry, this Advanced class is still perfect for you! Be a lighting expert from this point on! 

Lighting is not supposed to be brain surgery, but many filmmakers still make common mistakes. If you’ve been to one of our previous workshops, you’ll know that our method uses an intimate class with lots of HANDS ON EXPERIENCE over textbook theories to achieve SIMPLE, CREATIVE and EFFICIENT shooting techniques without tons of equipment, budget, crew or time.

This month we'll discuss "Jar City" by Arnaldur Indriðason.  Jar City introduces American readers to a new crime writer from Iceland.  When a lonely old man is found murdered in his Reykjavík flat, the only clues are a cryptic note left by the killer and a photograph of a young girl's grave. Inspector Erlendur, who heads the investigation team, discovers that many years ago the victim was accused, though not convicted, of an unsolved crime. Did the old man's past come back to haunt him?


The meeting will be hosted by Wendy at her house in White Plains. We will provide stuffed burgers. Please bring fruit salad, vegetables, potato salad, macaroni salad, appetizers, drinks or desserts. Let everyone know what you will be bringing by commenting on this meeting.  It would be nice if you could make what you bring seasonal themed.


Looking forward to seeing everyone on Saturday, 12/12/2015 at 11:30a.

CO-ED PICKUP SOCCER GAMES in Sara D. Roosevelt Park!

                                NO CLEATS or PLASTIC STUDS

                           See our page on Facebook!:

       facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CCuNsd9JXVE

Game description:

We'll play two simultaneous games of 7 on 7.
There will be 4 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field!
Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.
No power shots allowed.
If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.
If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.
Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game.
Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board on Friday night or before 12:00 PM on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location and Directions:

Sara D. Roosevelt Park, Nike Field
Take the F train to 2nd Avenue Lower East Side, and walk for about 3 minutes on Chrystie Street to the Nike Field between Stanton St & Rivington St
New York, NY 10002
Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.

What to bring with you:

A positive attitude, pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

Fee:


You will be asked to pay $9.50 dollars when you RSVP. This $9.50 dollars is used to pay for, permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled.
The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to Slánte for brunch and a Pint or Two:

                                                        Slánte

                                                  304 Bowery

                                           New York, NY 10012

                                               (212)[masked]

                                          www.slaintenyc.com

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
This is our regular three-hour figure drawing session plus our first:

Drawing New York - Art Supply Trade.

We will be drawing a live model from 12:00 - 3:00 pm as usual.  

From 3:00 - 4:00 we will have our art supply trade.

What is an art supply trade?

• Everyone that wants to participate is to bring in art supplies (good ones that are new or gently used) that they are willing to trade with other people who are bringing in art supplies they are willing to trade. (Bring as many as you like.)

• Attendees will respectfully negotiate TRADES with each other; i.e. "I will trade these oil pastels for that watercolor set."

• You can trade as many times as you wish or not at all if there is nothing you want.

• This is a great way to get value from your good (but unwanted) art supplies and get good (wanted) ones without spending any money. 

• This will be particularly helpful around the holiday season when we are spending our money on lots of other things. 

A few rules to keep it fun.


• No money (or promise of money) may exchange hands.

• No one is required to trade their supplies if there is nothing they want. 


• There are no "returns" of goods unless it is agreed to by both parties as another trade.


• Drawing New York is not responsible for the quality or safety of any products traded.  


• Art supplies are traded "as is" so you must check the quality before you trade. (Are the paints dried out, etc.)


Please email me with any questions. I look forward to seeing you there and hope to do this a couple of times a year. 


Sincerely, 

Simon 

Drawing New York

results.description:
The park, which receives approximately twenty-five million visitors annually, is the most visited urban park in the United States. It was opened on 770 acres (3.1 km) of city-owned land and was expanded to 843 acres (3.41 km; 1.317 sq mi). It is 2.5 miles (4 km) long between 59th Street (Central Park South) and 110th Street (Central Park North), and is 0.5 miles (0.8 km) wide between Fifth Avenue and Central Park West. It is similar in size to San Francisco's Golden Gate Park, Chicago's Lincoln Park, Vancouver's Stanley Park, and Munich's Englischer Garten.


Join EWNYC as we take a  walk through Central Park. The majority of the Park starting at 59th Street - to (hopefully) Harlem and back 59th street. This is a great opportunity to use our camera and enjoy the park that has been New York's staples from the beginning.


We meet at: Columbus Circle - One Train to 59th Street (by the Water Fountains) at 12:00 we start at 12:30

Details of the Walk

We start at 12:30, We will walk through the majority of the park, As well as several locations through out the park Bring your camera and food. Dress warm and appropriately It may be cold ( this is the best part of it)Please check your email in the morning (if raining we will reschedule)


If there are any questions please contact me
results.name: Central Park's NYC's - Fun Winter Walk

results.description:
** This class is for anyone who is completely new to improv and have been afraid to try it out. **

** You're welcome to stay and watch the Ensemble class that's happening right after this class ends. **

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

Anyone and everyone is welcome!

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

-----------------------------------------------

About Dewey Chaffee

Dewey has more than 20 years of improvisation experience. He spent 23 years perfecting his skills as an improv performer for the Walt Disney Company. He's also appeared on Nickelodeon Television and worked as their audience warm up guy for several seasons of TV production.

Currently, he and his husband perform a live improvised comedy drag show called "The Lady Winifred and Didi Show."

results.description:
I am a therapist, divorce mediator, and adjunct professor at NYU with a specialization in eating disorders. I am interested in helping to facilitate a monthly meet-up group to discuss experiences, treatment options, and helpful ideas in dealing with eating disorders of all types. I have years of experience treating bulimia, binge eating, anorexia, and issues of body image, with excellent results.


In addition to seeing patients individually for eating disorders (among other issues), I'm currently forming an ongoing, weekly therapy group for persons with eating disorders who are looking for something more ongoing and intensive. I work on a sliding fee scale, so I will do what I can to make it work for you. My approach is a combination of psychodynamic, cognitive-behavioral, and Buddhist principles, with a healthy dose of compassion and understanding!

Our meetups are held in Union Square, near 12th Street and University Place.

Please give me a call or email me if you think you might be interested in attending the meet-ups or in learning more about individual or group therapy. Space is somewhat limited, so if you are interested, it's best to call or email me right away.


Thank you!


Judie Stein, Ph.D., L.M.S.W.
Director
Stein Mediation & Family Center

results.description:
FYI did you know that December 12 is Frank Sinatra's birthday?  It's hard to imagine New York and New Jersey without Sinatra.  

This isn't an official Meetup per se, just wanted to pass some info along. Below is an article about some great events they're having at the Hoboken Museum.  Many other local venues will have activities honoring this icon's century birthday.

If you can't make it to the Hoboken Museum, or even if you can, on December 12 take a moment out of of your busy and enjoy listening to some classic Sinatra Music.

Link below to the classic "New York, New York"

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9KJQNMqVIug

https://www.hobokenmuseum.org/

Sinatra’s birthplace commemorates his 100th

Trenton, N.J. — Chicago was his kind of town, L.A. was his lady and he certainly was a big part of New York, New York. But despite a love-hate relationship, the mile-square New Jersey city where Frank Sinatra was born is finding the centennial of his birth to be a very good year.

Throughout 2015, Hoboken has remembered its native son, who died in 1998 at age 82, with outdoor screenings of his movies, a “Sinatra Idol” competition and concerts that will be capped by a centennial birthday bash on Dec. 12 at the Stevens Institute of Technology, which awarded the high school dropout an honorary degree in 1985.

The Hoboken Historical Museum has seen a 300 percent jump in visitors since opening a Sinatra exhibit in early August and has hired extra staff, director Robert Foster said.

“Whenever we do something on Sinatra, people come out of the woodwork,” Foster said. “We enjoy the fans because they are so loyal and he means so much to them.”

Lacking any major items that belonged to Sinatra, the museum tells his story through media displays and visitors receive a map with their $4 admission that features Sinatra sites.

http://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/11/29/sinatra-birthplace-centennial-hoboken/76543206/

Frank Sinatra

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Francis Albert "Frank" Sinatra (/sɨˈnɑːtrə/; December 12, 1915 – May 14, 1998) was an American jazz and traditional pop singer, actor, and producer, who was one of the most popular and influential musical artists of the 20th century. He is one of the best-selling music artists of all time, having sold more than 150 million records worldwide.[2] Born in Hoboken, New Jersey to Italian immigrants, he began his musical career in the swing era with Harry James and Tommy Dorsey. He found success as a solo artist after being signed by Columbia Records in 1943, becoming the idol of the "bobby soxers". He released his first album, The Voice of Frank Sinatra, in 1946. Sinatra's professional career had stalled by the early 1950s, and he turned to Las Vegas, where he became one of its best known performers as part of the Rat Pack. His career was reborn in 1953 with the success of From Here to Eternity and his subsequent Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. He signed with Capitol Records and released several critically lauded albums, including In the Wee Small Hours (1955), Songs for Swingin' Lovers! (1956), Come Fly with Me (1958), Only the Lonely(1958) and Nice 'n' Easy (1960).

Sinatra left Capitol in 1961 to start his own record label, Reprise Records, and released a string of successful albums. In 1965 he recorded the retrospective September of My Years, starred in the Emmy-winning television special Frank Sinatra: A Man and His Music, and scored hits with "Strangers in the Night" and "My Way". After releasing Sinatra at the Sands, recorded at the Sands Hotel and Casino in Vegas with frequent collaborator Count Basie in early 1966, the following year he recorded one of his most famous collaborations with Tom Jobim, the album Francis Albert Sinatra & Antonio Carlos Jobim. It was followed by 1968's collaboration withDuke Ellington. Sinatra retired for the first time in 1971, but came out of retirement two years later and recorded several albums and resumed performing at Caesars Palace. In 1980 he scored a Top 40 hit with "(Theme From) New York, New York". Using his Las Vegas shows as a home base, he toured both within the United States and internationally until a short time before his death in 1998.

Sinatra forged a highly successful career as a film actor. After winning an Academy Award for From Here to Eternity, he starred in The Man with the Golden Arm (1955), and received critical acclaim for his performance in The Manchurian Candidate (1962). He appeared in various musicals such as On the Town (1949), Guys and Dolls (1955), High Society (1956), and Pal Joey (1957), and towards the end of his career he became associated with playing detectives, including the title character in Tony Rome (1967). On television, The Frank Sinatra Show began on ABC in 1950, and he continued to make appearances on television throughout the 1950s and 1960s. Sinatra was also heavily involved with politics from the mid 1940s, and actively campaigned for presidents such as Harry S. Truman, John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan, though before Kennedy's death Sinatra's alleged Mafia connections led to him being snubbed.

While Sinatra never formally learned how to read music, he had a fine, natural understanding of it, and he worked very hard from a young age to improve his abilities in all aspects of music. A perfectionist, renowned for his impeccable dress sense and cleanliness, he always insisted on recording live with his band. Sinatra led a colorful personal life, and was often involved in turbulent affairs with women, such as with his second wife Ava Gardner. He went on to marry Mia Farrow in 1966 and Barbara Marx in 1976. Sinatra experienced several violent confrontations, usually journalists who he felt had crossed him or work bosses he had disagreements with. He was honored at the Kennedy Center Honors in 1983 and was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by Ronald Reagan in 1985 and the Congressional Gold Medal in 1997. Sinatra was also the recipient of eleven Grammy Awards, including the Grammy Trustees Award, Grammy Legend Award and the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award. After his death, American music criticRobert Christgau called him "the greatest singer of the 20th century",[3] and he continues to be seen as an iconic figure.[4]

results.name: FYI: Frank Sinatra's 100th Birthday

results.description:
This powerful photo was taken by ShaylinJanelle photography (http://shaylinjanelle.tumblr.com/)

Healing from child sexual abuse is a journey that does not have an end date. However, the healing process begins with stopping the lonely and painful cycle of secrecy. Remember, you are not alone! Survivors are everywhere.


Each year in the U.S. more than 300,000 children are sexually abused. In fact, in the U.S. alone, there are approximately 60 million survivors of child sexual abuse (CSA). It's an abuse that is indiscriminate, cutting across gender, race, culture, familial socio-economic status, religion and other diversities.


ALTSDS Church is committed to addressing child sexual abuse prevention & is part of CONNECTNYC’s Safe Faith Community Project (SFCP) designed to work with faith communities/churches to engage in education, advocacy, and organizing to eradicate child sexual abuse.

Join ALTSDS Church on Saturday, December 12, 2015 in a service to honor the value, dignity and humanity of child sexual abuse survivors.

Special Guest Speaker & CSA Educator: DeShannon Barnes-Bowens, M.S., ILERA Founder, Psychotherapist & Author of Hush Hush (http://ilera.com/hush-hush)

"There is beauty in every soul. There is value in every person. There is hope that is stronger than your pain! You are a survivor!" | Clara Hinton, Child Sexual Abuse Advocate

Learn more about CONNECTNYC here: http://www.connectnyc.org/
results.name: Finding Voice in the Unspeakable: Honoring Survivors of Child Sexual Abuse

"The Unspeakable Subject of Hieronymus Bosch" can be viewed at 

https://video.ias.edu/unspeakable-subject

If the link doesn't work then copy and paste the url into your browser search window. 

From the time of its original display through the present day, the subject of Hieronymus Bosch's so-called "Garden of Delights" has eluded audiences. In a lecture devoted to what is arguably the most enigmatic work in the history of art, Professor Joseph Leo Koerner examines why Bosch's subject was made deliberately unspeakable and from whose perspective is this garden delightful. The lecture is part of the Art as Knowledge series, which features talks by leading art historians on the subject of how art develops and conveys knowledge.

results.name: The Unspeakable Subject of Hieronymus Bosch

results.description:
Meet to share and discuss SF and fantasy writing, books, films, TV shows, the writing process, the publishing industry, etc. with other SF and fantasy writers (both published and unpublished).  We usually have a long and lively discussion, followed by critiques of stories or chapters (if any) that members brought along.  We don't always have stories to critique, but we usually enjoy having hours worth of discussion, so let us know near the beginning of the Meetup if you brought something to have critiqued so we don't use up all our time talking -- time flies when you're having fun!

Further details or topics for this Meetup may be announced later.

As usual, you can bring a chapter or short story for the group to critique, but it's by no means necessary.  If you do bring your MS, try to bring enough paper copies for everyone attending to have one, and if you want us to write comments or corrections on it, then please double-space it.  We usually ask the author to read it aloud (unless you're shy), which is very helpful, because you'd be surprised how often you don't catch your own mistakes until you read your manuscript aloud for the first time! 

For the manuscript (MS) critiques, length is not set in stone, but suggested length is 1500 words, maximum length 3000 words. In pages (Times 12 point font), 1500 words is just under five pages double spaced, or about three pages single-spaced (but you should always double-space to allow room for people to write comments or corrections!)  Don't worry if your MS is longer than 1500 words, you can still bring it, but please keep it under 3,000 words.

For more guidelines on critiques, see http://www.meetup.com/The-Woodbridge-Science-Fiction-Fantasy-Writers-Meetup/about/
results.name: Share and discuss writing with other SF and fantasy writers

results.description:
Ever wondered where the Greeks got the idea for naked statues?  Or exactly what is going on in those painted scenes on the vases?  Aren't there a lot of gay scenes?  We all know that the Greeks and Romans had very different ideas about sexuality--and in particular the same-sex side--than modern people.   It's also obvious that there's a lot of sexy stuff going on in Classical art, but it's pretty baffling to a modern viewer:  you need a lot of context, or else you miss out on the fun part!  So....welcome to my world.  As many in our meet-up know, I am the founder of Oscar Wilde Tours, the gay history and art tour company:  I gave one of my LGBT tours of the Met for our group earlier this year, and people seemed to really enjoy it.  We really have to rush through the Classical galleries on those tours, though, because there is so much more material there than we have time for--and also because that is my academic specialty:  same-sex love in Classical art.  So recently I have started giving a second tour of the Met, so we can linger in the Greek and Roman galleries.  We look at the very different histories of the male and female nude, evidence for male-male and female-female love, plus a host of other issues:  sexy drinking games, the loves of the gods, the role of the god Eros, plus the Emperor Hadrian and the boyfriend he turned into a god.  Join us for a romp through Classical art and ancient sexualities.

Price:  $35 (a $14 discount over normal price).  Students and Met members $20.  You have to pay $20 to RSVP; people who are not students or Met members can pay the rest at the event (in cash or by credit card).  Sorry if this is expensive, but the Met insists on full payment from people in groups; unfair, but what can one do?

results.name: Ancient Sex/ualities at the Met

And for those of you who have a board, please bring it. We look forward to playing with you! Also, to ensure that we have enough boards for all attendees, please bring your board and mention it in your RSVP. Thanks

results.description:
• ABSOLUTELY NO CLEATS ALLOWED (for both real grass and artificial grass)! NO EXCEPTIONS!! PLEASE WEAR TURF SHOES OR INDOOR SHOES.

• Permit Disclosure: WE HAVE A PERMIT.

• BRING A WHITE SHIRT AND A DARK SHIRT

• We play rain or shine!

(Leader- Braulio)
(Co-Leader- JP Matiz)

We're partnering with Brooklyn/Queens Soccer Club to bring you this game in good ol' Flushing Meadows Park. Much thanks to them for providing the field space. 

You can catch them and their games by clicking HERE.

• PLEASE ARRIVE EARLY TO START ON TIME !! Game starts when we have at least 10 players.

Rules explained at the game.

Be Positive - Constructive criticism after the game is way better than you yelling at me and complaining during the game.

Be Safe- Want to kick someone really hard? go take jiujitsu. We like our shins.


Be 2! - Teamwork. It takes 2 to complete every pass.

Be Generous! - Not just your money (though it helps). We want clapping and good cheers.

The proceeds go to our charity network: http://ps2g.org/charities

**All RSVPs are final. No credits or refunds. (It's all for charity anyway)**

• Minimum 10 RSVPs needed for game. Games will be canceled if this number is not reached 1 hour before Game Time (not meetup time).  

If the game is canceled, request a refund by filling out this form.

If you can't afford the meetup fees, please visit our website to learn how to become a game leader. Game Leaders play for free. http://ps2g.org/gameleaders

PS2G raises money for charities that use soccer for social good restoring dignity where it's been lost through the game of soccer. We share the impact of this movement through multiple channels and promote generosity on the field through safe and supportive play.

PS2G - Local Game. Global Change. 

Disclaimer By taking part in group activities you hereby are agreeing to the rules and regulation of the meetup. In addition, you acknowledge you are volunteering to play at your own self will and at your own risk. Neither organizer nor assistant organizers are responsible for any injuries or mishaps while partaking in the games. We encourage love of the game and for each other. We encourage friendly competition. Organizers reserve the right to remove players from the game if they refuse to be friendly.

We will be charging $15 per meeting to cover the cost of renting the studio.  There is a significant discount for purchasing the entire semester which includes 14 2 hour classes.

We have some equipment to lend, but if you would like to borrow, please contact me at least 24 hours before the meetup, and let me know if you are left handed.

- Mike

results.description:
This meditation is part of "Blast Open Your Heart" Public Meditation Service series that is designed to help you stay present, joyful and healthy.  

Very good for all artistic and those who feel that they have no artistic talents.

Laughing is the mediation that everyone is already practicing.  You loose your boundaries when you laugh, and you connect to your source.You loosed your sense of self when you possessed by the laughter.If you observe yourself, you will realize that you can not laugh and think at the same time.When you are laughing suddenly, you will experience the moment when thought is no longer possible.  You experience No Mind

Please bring water, paper, pen, and a blindfold (optional). 

It is a free event.

This is a co-ed adult pick-up game 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe and is free for those who attended both training sessions with him the same day, $4 for all others.


PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP AT LEAST 2 HOURS BEFORE THE GAME!

• Update your RSVP by 11:30AM

• RSVPs close by 12 NOON

• No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP at least 2 hours before the game will be red carded after the second offense, which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.

Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.

results.description:
CO-ED PICKUP SOCCER GAMES in Sara D. Roosevelt Park!

                       NO CLEATS or PLASTIC STUDS

                           See our page on Facebook!:

       facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TS2aJpXPgho

Game description:
We'll play two simultaneous games of 7 on 7.
There will be 4 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team.

RULES OF THE GAME:
First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field!
Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.
No power shots allowed.
If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.
If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.
Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game.
Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board on Friday night or before 12:00 PM on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location and Directions:

Sara D. Roosevelt Park, Nike Field
Take the F train to 2nd Avenue Lower East Side, and walk for about 3 minutes on Chrystie Street to the Nike Field between Stanton St & Rivington St
New York, NY 10002
Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.

What to bring with you:
A positive attitude, pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

Fee:
You will be asked to pay $9.50 dollars when you RSVP. This $9.50 dollars is used to pay for, permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:
Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled.
The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to Slánte for brunch and a Pint or Two:

                                                        Slánte

                                                  304 Bowery

                                           New York, NY 10012

                                               (212)[masked]

                                          www.slaintenyc.com

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

-Beginners are welcome, but you must be a good swimmer.

-You MUST bring a lock for a gym locker.

-You should bring an athletic bathing suit, goggles, and a towel. Bring a swim cap if you have long hair.

results.description:
>>> PURCHASE TICKETS HERE <<<

PLEASE BYPASS the RSVP button at right and register directly above. If you are a dues-paying Member of Out Professionals, this assures you no-cost or low-cost admission to this event. (Nonmembers are always welcome, but nonmember rates apply if you are just part of our Meetup group.) For a full year of Member savings and other career benefits, join Out Professionals here.

COME WINDOW-HOPPING WITH OUT PROFESSIONALS ON A SPECIAL HOLIDAY TOUR DESIGNED FOR US BY WALK ABOUT NEW YORK.

On Saturday afternoon, December 12, Out Professionals invites you to relive the joys of holidays past at “Holiday Window-Hopping,” a spirited tour of the most storied of Midtown’s Christmas windows — original works of art soon to disappear.

This private tour is designed for us by Walk About New York. We begin at Lord & Taylor, the oldest luxury department store in North America. Then we’re off to Macy’s, Saks Fifth Avenue, Henri Bendel, Tiffany & Co., Bergdorf Goodman, Van Cleef & Arpels, Barneys and Bloomingdale’s. Afterwards, you’re welcome to unwind among new friends at TownHouse New York (“Cozy without crossing the line to stuffy” — New York Magazine).

Some of the tour’s surprises:

• Which technological advancement led to window shopping?

• Which store puts its windows in place using hydraulic lifts?

• Which popular toy began by livening up a window display?

• Which well-known Christmas character got its start in a window?

• Which artist inconceivably created windows for the late Bonwit Teller?

Tour Director Phil Desiere, founder of Walk About New York, is licensed by the city as a tour guide. In addition to conducting tours of such quintessential spots as Central Park and Greenwich Village, Phil develops and leads tours of Brooklyn’s Green-Wood Cemetery, a National Historic Landmark.

WHAT’S UP

On Saturday, December 12, we meet Phil Desiere at 1:45 p.m. on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 38th Street, diagonally opposite Lord & Taylor, a National Historic Landmark. Subway: B/D/F/M to 42nd Street Bryant Park; D/F/N/Q/R to 34th Street Herald Square. Tour begins at 2 p.m. sharp and takes place rain or shine. It involves stairs and use of your MetroCard. Afterwards, unwind at TownHouse New York, 236 East 58th Street; refreshments on your own.

ADMISSION

Nonmember, $25. Dues-paying OP Member, just $15. Please print and pocket a copy of your online receipt. The personalized nature of our tours requires us to limit the number of participants. At the door, if available, cash only.

IT PAYS TO BE AN OP MEMBER!

A 12-month individual Out Professionals Membership (new or renewal) PLUS admission for one to “Holiday Window-Hopping: The Walking Tour and Mixer” is yours for just $75. And remember, that buys you a year’s worth of low-cost or no-cost networking and socializing. Order here.
results.name: Let's Meetup and Walk the Holiday Windows!

results.description:
Basic Ground Rules for Participation

Please wear either a blue/black or white shirt to make things easy (Preferably bring both in case we need to mix the teams more evenly).


no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc. If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF. If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...). If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.

What is Ultimate Frisbee? In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee. You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.

results.description:
****READ THIS FIRST || Parade Grounds Game Standards ****


Meet on field 8!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 2:00. We typically start 15 minutes after 2:00. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
Our typical agenda: - We orient new visitors and then chat a bit, as by sharing what's new or good in our lives. - Then we chant and meditate together, together with the beautiful sounds of a gong - And finally we share thoughts and questions, learning something new sometimes, generally supporting each other best we can at all times.

Note that we meet every Wednesday, 7:30 to 9 pm, and every Saturday, 2 to 3:30 pm on Midchester Ave. -- except for the first Saturday of the month, when we meet elsewhere and begin our meeting at 5 pm, followed by an informal potluck social starting about 7 pm.

(When you plan on staying for the potluck, see the log-in information posted at our monthly potluck page. That helps us get healthy, balanced meals.)

By the way, the meetup page may show only a few members planning to attend a particular meeting. That's because many people attend regularly and don't bother to RSVP for each meeting.  We never have only a few members at a meeting. Twenty members more usually attend each meeting.

Call Merrill or Mataji anytime you have questions:[masked]-5334.

results.description:
Hey everyone!

First off, let's answer some big questions everyone's been asking:

Q: Is this group dead or alive?


A: As you can see...WE'RE STILL ALIVE!

Q: Awesome…but what happened to our spring/summer Meetups this year?


A: We quietly took a bit of an unplanned, first-ever sabbatical over the last several months due to (of all things) global warming.


In short, this tough decision was largely done for the safety of our snort-nosed pals - read more about the reasons why in a recent reply I made on our discussion forum here:


http://www.meetup.com/newyorkbostonterrier/messages/boards/thread/49092914#[masked]  

Q: Well, TLDR...why didn't we do them indoors at Animal Haven?


A: In short, due to logistics (again, see discussion link above) - and as I've learned recently, their air conditioning in the playroom was broken and remained so for much of the summer, so it wouldn't have even been an option anyway.

Q: It's December, and by now we'd be into our second winter indoor Meetup at Animal Haven - and we didn't even do one in November…why?


A: Animal Haven as we've known and loved it for so many years is no more.


They've moved a couple of blocks down the street into a brand new, smaller, LEED-certified facility - read more about it here:


http://www.animalhavenshelter.org/site/PageServer?pagename=Moving


This is great…except for one thing:


It now has a play space that's 1/4th the size of the their old one.

Sadly, this now presents a few BIG problems for us - which I hope you guys can help us out with:

- Put simply, we're a victim of our own success. We have one of the largest pet owner groups on Meetup.com in NYC. However, we simply cannot do indoor Meetups in a space that size.


- We've been looking into new venues like privately-owned doggie daycare places, and so far, none I've seen have a play space of comparable size, or are open to the notion of accommodating 30-40 dogs and their owners showing up at once (at least in Manhattan, where we try to remain centrally-based for everyone).


- From a "business standpoint", this is kind of a big deal in another way:

A small portion of the proceeds from our winter Meetups have historically funded the group for the remainder of the year, the rest was donated to Animal Haven - any new space we find would need to be both economical and still amenable to sharing any income so we can pay our twice-yearly Meetup.com group subscription, which increased this year due to our group's size to $180/year.


To be perfectly honest, this has all taken us and many other NYC dog Meetup organizers completely by surprise.


Animal Haven has been our go-to indoor venue since the group was founded in 2006, and frankly, we hadn't thought of any other options, because we never needed to. They've essentially been woven into our DNA from the start, and gave us no early indication or warning they had plans to move until we approached them several weeks ago to schedule this winter's Meetups. Regardless, they've otherwise been good to us over the years, and we wish them the best of luck with their mission in their new space!

Soooo…for the first time, we're now needing to turn to you, and asking for your ideas to help keep our group alive.

If you know of a venue in the city that can meet our needs - doggie daycare, private residence, a business with a large, safe, well-appointed space with dog-friendly owners, etc. - PLEASE get in touch ASAP, so we can check into it, and hopefully get us back on track for the winter sooner rather than later. 

(End of explanation/apology/support plea section...now, as for the more immediate future, and that aforementioned global warming thing, back to our regularly scheduled program...)

Perhaps you've noticed it's a little hot out for December, huh? 


Not only did we globally have the hottest spring, summer, and fall on record, NYC may see the warmest days in December history this weekend.


Normally, this could be seen as a bad thing, but right now for us under the circumstances - it's AWESOME…so to celebrate, and make up for lost time a little bit, we'll have not one but TWO Meetups this weekend!


#1 will be at the Stuyvesant Dog Run just a few blocks east of Union Square on Saturday, #2 will be uptown at Teddy's Run next to the American Museum of Natural History at 79th and Columbus Avenue.


RSVPs are obviously not required since we're outdoors, but would be greatly appreciated so we can get an idea of who's coming.

Normally this would be considered very short notice, which we apologize profusely for, but I wanted to ensure the forecasts would be good - so let's enjoy this gift of fall-like temps while we can.

Happy Holidays to all!

-Scott
Fearless Leader/Alpha Doggie Organizer
NYC Boston Terrier Meetup Group
results.name: December Double Outdoor/Global Warming Meetup (#1 of 2 this weekend!)

This is one of my favorite tours in 1 of my favorite places. Harlem is an area where we have many memorials and tributes to many who fought for Civil Rights. We will pass by Frederick Douglass Jr. Circle,Columbia University (where I went to school), 3 parks, President Grant's Tomb and even our current president's old residence. We'll end up by Grant's Tomb.

Please note  the $15 MeetUp Member charge per person for this special tour. Discount price for students and senior citizens is offered at $12. This tour's value is actually $250 (for 10 people) as that is my charge for most of my private tours. Kindly provide me with exact payment at the venue.

  Like my other walks, I do not plan  to cancel the walk as this is a multi group event.  Also since I set  a 30 person limit, please cancel your RSVP if you decide your initial plans have changed. 


Please feel free to text or call me at[masked] with any questions.

You may also want to click on the below link so you can become a fellow Artful Walking Talking Detective meet up member:
http://www.meetup.com/Artful-Fun-Interactive-NYC-Area-Fact-Finding-Walkers/

Cindy Ladopoulos- www.NYCindyTours.com

results.description:
ABOUT THE PROGRAM The NYC Community Kayak Pool Program will begin at Riverbank State Park on Saturday, November 15, 2014 and runs through the beginning of March 7, 2015. The program provides basic kayak training to the public through the New York State Department of Parks in an Olympic size pool overlooking the Hudson River. These weekly classes are to introduce students to kayak equipment and learn basic strokes and safety. The program relies on instructors / volunteers from the kayak community.

Head Instructor Lee Reiser donates his time throughout the season. Lee is an ACA Level II Certified Instructor. He are assisted by individuals with a wide range of experience and certifications from the American Canoe Association and the British Canoe Union, two of themajor organizations for the sport of recreational kayaking.

Course 1 Saturdays November 14, 21,December 6,13


You must double click the link or go to:   NYC Community Kayak Program 2015- 2016 under the file section.

Registration is required by completing that information and returning it to:

Please send an email to Audrey Jackson. Program Coordinator [masked] orLee Reiser [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: By Car: From 138th Street head west and make a left onto 12th Avenue.
results.name: NYC Community Kayak Pool Program

group.name: Hudson River and Beyond  Kayaking Club

results.description:
This group has been around for a looooong time, and on December 12, 2015, we're going to have our 500th meeting. (Yeah, I keep track.) So let's celebrate.

My mom has offered to host at her spacious apartment in the West 70s. We've met there several times before, but it's been years. She has no pets, and other than two or three steps to get into the lobby, it's wheelchair accessible.

This is going to be a potluck, so when you RSVP, please leave a comment and let everyone know what you're bringing -- or message me directly. I'll compile a list and post updates. That way we'll end up with a variety of food and drinks. Don't bring anything that needs to be cooked from scratch. If you need to heat stuff up in the microwave or throw something in the fridge or freezer, that's fine.

After the meeting, we'll head over to my place (which is six blocks away) and keep the party going.

The night before this meeting, I'll send more info including the address to people who RSVP.
results.name: Writing group meeting/party/potluck on the Upper West Side

results.description:
This is my second year attending this valuable program. Under Lee Reiser, ACA level ll instructor, will help you hone your existing skills, learn new ones properly and introduce new people to the world of kayaking. In a beautiful heated pool with all kayaks and gear provided you can train for 2 hours learning bracing, rolling, rescues etc. and in return help the public for 2 hours by setting up and putting equipment away, greeting the public students, assisting instructors etc. All level of kayakers are welcome. The sessions are as follows:
Course 1 Saturday - Nov. 14,21; Dec. 5, 12
Course 2 " - Jan. 9, 16, 23, 30
Course 3 " - Feb. 6, 13, 27; March 5
The time for volunteers to practice is from 3 to 4 pm and the time to volunteer is from 4 to 6 pm. Please arrive at least 15 minutes before so you can get ready. Pack a small bag with your change of clothes. The pool is heated but you may want to wear a wet suit, bringing your own PFD, paddle and skirt can add to your comfort level. Pack a small bag with a change of clothes, towel etc and bring a lock for the lockers.
Please fill out the volunteer packet which can be obtained from the Yonkers Club site: http://www.yprc.org
click on the Riverbank link once you are in the site and download the NY community Kayak Program packet. If you commit to at least 1 session you will be provided with a parking pass.

DIRECTIONS- From 138th St. head west and make a left onto 12th Ave., Take the 1st right beneath the West Side Hwy (by the restaurant) then swing right again past the first guard booth. Follow the roadway in and around, curve left and make a hard left U-turn into the parking area. Use the elevator to get to the park on the upper level walk to the pool area. Make sure you have a parking permit in your car window. Please car pool as parking is limited.
PLEASE SEE DEC 5, 2015 FOR MORE INFORMATION
results.name: Volunteer, learn new skills and kayak at the NY Community Kayak Program.

This is a class in technique although, when you've conquered a song technically, then I will coach musicality and performance. Class size is limited. Fee is $20/per. You may audit the class once (without participating) for $10. Let me know when you sign up if that's your intention.

   People at the front desk are helpful and friendly and the Cafe on the floor has great coffee and cookies, sandwiches, <a>pizza</a>, etc.

   I've been asked to post this:

Dear Members:  This is the first you have heard from me. I am Mr. Harrington's agent/rep. Mr. Harrington teaches privately coaching established actors and singers. For years his private rate has been $120/hr for this service. He started teaching through Meetup earlier this year and has as his goal to bring professional level instruction to the public at a rate that leaves no one behind. This demands tight scheduling of both his time and the room rental with Ripley-Grier Studios.For these reasons, I will be insisting to him that "no shows" be dropped from the group. The policy is this: If you RSVP you better show up. If you cancel you better do this by 4:00 pm the previous day.A word to the wise...Michael T. Harvey

I'll usually let everyone know by Wednesday which room we'll be in on Saturday.

The rooms cost $70 for all three hours. We divide the cost equally.

results.description:
You're cordially invited to join us for the Second Annual Holiday Party!  We had so much fun doing it last year, we'll continue the tradition!

----------------------------------------------------------

Part I:  Small group discussions with the following themes:


* 2015: Year in Review -- what were the most important, or  perhaps the most under-reported stories / events?

** PLUS, predictions for 2016.

*** BUT, most importantly -- what did the Year 2015 mean to you personally?  . . . in terms of how certain public policies or events affected your life or your personal views regarding your community and the world?  A ripe moment to re-evaluate, before we head in to a New Year.

Part II: Dinner at a nearby restaurant

----------------------------------------------------------


RSVP instructions [IMPORTANT -- PLEASE READ IN ENTIRETY]:  

• You can start RSVPing now.

• There will be approximately twenty spots and a priority will be given to those who previously attended an NYCPF meetup.  

• Each attendee can bring one guest, but please be sure to mark accordingly when you RSVP. 

• If you're a new member or haven't previously attended our meetups, we look forward to welcoming you at the next regular meetup. 

• Although there are no fees required to attend, each attendee is responsible for paying for their own bill for food and / or drinks.

Although you are not obligated to participate in the gift exchange to attend the party, isn't it always fun to open presents?!


If you'd like to participate in the Secret Santa Gift Exchange please answer the sample questions when you rsvp. The sign up deadline has already passed but no worries. You will be matched up whenever someone else signs up.

Gift Exchange Guidelines:  1 skein project (yay for stash yarn!) OR a gift with a minimum value of $25.00   

Sample questions you may want to ask your Secret Santa are: Favorite or least favorite colors? Any fiber allergies? Head circumference? Shoe Size?   An item they might need or want? Ask anything that will give you an idea of what your Secret Santa would enjoy.  Have FUN!

FIND OUT THE ANSWERS TO THESE QUESTIONS:

• Who is the original man? 

• Who are the mother and father of civilization? 

• Who gave reading, writing, mathematics and science to the world? 

• Where is the birthplace of civilization?

Accomplished lecturer, author, TV personality, and tour guide, Jabari Osaze has studied African History for over 25 years, focusing on areas of philosophy, esoteric symbols, and sacred science.  An Ancient Egyptian priest, Brother Osaze has led study groups in Egypt since 2002 and tours of the world-renowned Egyptian collections of New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, Univ. of Penn’s Museum of Archeology and Anthropology and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo.
