results.description:
It’s time to celebrate Christmas, Hanukkah and the New Year as Midtown Manhattan lights up like no other place in the world.  Mechanical window displays, synchronized light and sound shows, not to mention Santa Claus and toy soldiers surely await you in this winter wonderland. 


All year round, New York City offers fabulous tours of all kinds, but there is nothing on the planet like New York City during the winter holidays, when the entire City just sparkles. A great tour for December is the Holiday Lights Tour, escorting you all over NYC to see the lights and decorations in full swing.

 Its a fun night to Manhattan and we Start With a 

W Full Dinner At Natalie's in Ridgewood 

After Dinner... We have  Deluxe Motor Coach Tour to NYC For a few Great Holiday stops in NYC. 

We will "Meet Up'@ Natalies in Ridgewood 

(A Local Favorite since 1993) 

Please Come @ 3:30pm  for a Full course Dinner w Dessert.  (All Taxes and Gratuities Included )

BYOB if you like... Please Next Store

After Dinner We are off  to NYC for a Fabous Tour 


1st Stop : The Union Square Holiday Market is the New York destination for an intimate and enjoyable holiday shopping experience. Allow yourself the time to slow down and wander through the holly-lined aisles, and connect with the artisans from near and far who are selling their wares and sharing their stories. It's a delightful place to get swept up in the festive spirit.

1 HR

2nd Winter Village at Bryant Park Over 100 differs Kiosks (1 Hr)

3rd Stop- Saks Windows (new themes each year) along Fifth Avenue that pop up to coincide with the merriest, splendidest time of the year. 


4th. The world-famous ice rink at Rockefeller Center has been a quintessential NYC experience for generations, set in the unique urban backdrop of Rockefeller Center's sparkling lights and holiday tree. 

Bring your friends, family and loved ones to make magical memories on ice that you will cherish for years to come.An array of warm and indulgent food and beverage, from authentic Persian soup to rich hot chocolate Local, handmade jewelry and accessories Gifts for children, teens, and the young-at-heart Artwork, from posters to framed prints and more Socially-conscious goods (look for our Artisan Pledge stickers to verify that products are 100% made in USA, local, organic, fair trade certified, recycled, and/or handmade) Home goods, from bowls crafted from natural olive wood to coasters made of slate Candles, soaps, and skin care products for men and women Winter accessories like scarves, hats, and gloves Gourmet pantry items, from small-batch jams to all natural olive oils 

After a GREAT night. We are back to Natalie's in Ridgewood


Just us Worry Free night... 

NO PARKING . NO DRIVING , No TOLLS , No HASSLE-


ALL FOR ONLY $89.00pp- Includes -Complete Dinner 

All Tax and  Gratuities  for Restaurant  and  Driver

Please send Your -PAYMENTs in  send TO SECURE YOU SEAT 

To "ROBERT GILLIGAN", PO BOX 184, Ridgewood, NJ 07451

Questions ? [masked]

or Cell[masked]

Thanks, Robert

Dinner Menu:

1. Appetizer -

2.  Salads

3. Entrees from a Section of Delicious Menu Favorites to Choose From 

4., Dessert -W Coffee Or Tea 

all Tax and Tips Included. 

PLEASE NOTE: PAYMENTS MUST BE MADE TO SECURE YOUR SEAT ON THE BUS. SO PLEASE SEND PAYMENT. 

Questions ? [masked]

or[masked]

results.description:
Trail Details: We'll run two 6.5 mile loops around South Mountain Reservation. During the first loop it will be getting dark. During the second loop it will be dark. Join us for both loops or choose your loop. If you’d like to run the second loop, meet us at the Locust Grove Parking lot at approx. 5:00 pm. This run is mostly on the moderate bridle/carriage trails. As always, we encourage all speeds to join, no matter how fast or slow.

Public Transit: Take the 3:11 pm NJ Transit Morristown line from Penn Station to the Millburn station (travel time 45 minutes). The walk from the station to the trail head is less than a quarter mile. For the second loop take the 4:11 pm train.

By Car: Meet us at the Locust Grove Parking Lot.

Bag Drop/Etc: There is always a bush or a pile of leaves to stash your stuff in, just make sure everything important is on you while you run. Sometimes BTR members who own cars show up at this location. Tearing up the town of Millburn is an optional post run activity, we can take a vote.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be wearing BTR shirts and looking like trail runners with headlamps on.

results.description:
Ladies there are many many vegan vendors at Bryant park this year and we need to go eat it all!

Ice skating : rental is $19/pp and open until 9PM.

The larger veg meetup group describes the vegan wonderland as follows:

The park is set up like a fairytale winter wonderland, with a sparkling tree, a delightful skating rink, beautiful holiday decorations everywhere, and holiday, artist and food vendors in charming kiosks throughout the park -- these do beautifully add to the holiday spirit of the place, you will see (while you are sipping on your hot apple cider with cinnamon stick). 

MOREOVER, AS IF ALL THAT WEREN'T ENOUGH, BRYANT PARK IS -- AMAZINGLY -- A *VEGAN* WONDERLAND. HERE'S WHAT YOU'LL SEE. (AND WHERE YOU WILL EAT!): One 100% Vegan food vendor(Chimney Cakes), right next to another 100% Vegan food vendor(Pickle Me Pete), which is a few feet away from another 100% Vegan food vendor (Marty's V-Burger). Across the way is another100% Vegan food vendor (Lucky Sailor), which is right next to another 100% Vegan food vendor (Soup for the Soul). Nearby isThis Pie is Nuts (delicious 100% Vegan pies from the amazing Diana Cornell). Near This Pie is Nuts is a delightful newcomer:Kaleidoscope - they are 100% Vegan! Across the park is Vegushi --100% Vegan sushi! Right next to Vegushi is one of my longtime favorites -- Big Apple Cider: hot apple cider, with or without a cinnamon stick -- I say with! -- which is also of course 100% Vegan!

Then there is 100% Vegan newcomer Super Mac + Cheez, which is right next to Saj Mahal (100% Vegan). And finally, there is the 100% Vegan newcomer Vedge. All together Bryant Park features twelve 100% Vegan food vendors, along with other food vendors that have vegan options!
results.how_to_find_us: Call Alexandra 609 610 6225

results.description:
Brooklyn has always been a place with a strong love for food.  Now it is more true than ever.  And with the approach of the holidays (many of which have a strong focus on food) I thought it could be a fun theme for our December Booze and Book Club.

At our last, fun meeting, I noticed, many of us have very varied interests.  So I thought it would be good, to see how well things worked, if we all stuck to the same topic, rather than the same book.  For this month's discussion, select a book, with food, as a main focal point.  It can be fiction, non-fiction, or something in between.  Down below, are some popular suggestions, divided by category.  Don't feel obligated to read one from the list.  And for those of you that want to join us, for drinks, and just, hear, what we've read that is fine, too. 


Fiction:

The 100 foot Journey - Richard C Morais


A Movable Feast - Ernest Hemingway  

The Belly of Paris - Emile Zola

Chocolate - Joanne Harris

The Macaroni is in the Basement - Fran Claro

Like Water for Chocolate - Laura Esquival

Food Memoirs:

Kitchen Confidential - Anthony Bourdain

Yes Chef - Marcus Samuelsson

Blood Bones and Butter Gabrielle Hamilton

Devil in the Kitchen - Marco Pierre White

The Man Who Ate Everything - Jeffrey Steingarten

The Ethical Butcher - Berlin Reed

Brooklyn/New York Food Stuff

The Slice Harvester (pizza lover's memoir) - Colin Atrophy

The Bagel: the Surprising history of a modest bread

Gastropolis: food and New York city

The Knish: in Search for the Jewish Soul

Save the Deli David Sax

Eat the City: A Tale of the Fishers, Foragers, Butchers, Farmers, Poultry Minders, Sugar Refiners, Cane Cutters, Beekeepers, Winemakers, and Brewers Who Built New York By Robin Shulman

Non-Fiction

Salt A World History - Mark Kurlansky

The Omnivore's Dilemma - Michael Pollan


Consider the Fork - Bee Wilson

The Drunken Botanist - Amy Stewart

Buzz: Urban Bee Keeping - Lisa Jean Moore

I should be easy to spot in the bar but just in case my cell is[masked] 2767.

Happy reading!
results.name: Brooklyn Booze + Book Club

So far the weather is looking ideal for this ride, but remember it will get cooler as the sun sets, dress accordingly.
Here are the details

Dyker Heights Christmas Lights Night Tour!!
Saturday, December 12th.
Meeting at: Prospect Park (Parkside & Ocean Ave.)
Time: 4:pm-7:30pm
Distance: 15-20 miles estimated!
Terrain: ALL FLAT!!!
Pace: We ride with the flow of traffic.
Fee: $10 for guidance and support.
MUST: Wear helmet, front and rear bike lights on bike.
Bring snacks you can eat while riding or at stops.
Please RSVP if planning to attend and contact with questions.
Avery
results.name: Christmas Lights Night Tour!!

results.description:
A recreational tap class for adults in a bar! 21+

4:00 pm Lesson I (perfect for beginners)

5:00 pm Lesson II (more advanced, tap shoes required)

$10 for one session, $17 for both!

$1 off all drinks at the bar. 
Please arrive 5-10 min before session to sign-in and get a drink.

If you have never tapped before or if it's been a while since you have, please come to Session I. This session introduces you to tap basics such as shuffles and flaps and then puts these skills into a fun, easy combination. (This can also be used as a warm-up for Session II). If you don't have tap shoes, please wear or bring closed-toe shoes such as sneakers.

If you own tap shoes and have at least a basic knowledge of tap fundamentals, you are welcome to attend Session II. This session moves faster than Session I and uses more advanced steps such as drawbacks and pullbacks in a fun, more advanced combination.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to ask!

Now we all know that Lucas screwed up the remastered version and we don't want to watch that again!  BUT JUST WAIT--- We have gotten our hands on a fan based remaster of the original movie.  Beautiful picture and all the original scenes.

So yes--- Han Shot first!

results.description:
Click the link below to RSVP to this free event (it will help us with head count!):

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ny-adventure-club-community-day-dyker-heights-christmas-lights-tickets-19883282433

Join New York Adventure Club on Saturday, December 12th, as we visit the Brooklyn neighborhood of Dyker Heights for their annual Christmas Lights extravaganza!

This tradition started in 1986 when Dyker Heights resident Lucy Spata decided to install a large Christmas lights display on her property after her mother passed away. While her neighbors first complained, they eventually joined in and turned the quiet neighborhood into a holiday destination that attracts nearly 100,000 visitors to the area in December.

After we walk around the neighborhood, we'll grab food and drinks back near the 86th St. station in Bay Ridge!
results.name: NY Adventure Club Community Day: Dyker Heights Christmas Lights

At Teaneck Meditation we use a very simple, yet direct way of cleansing and freeing the mind. This meditation is a customized guided practice through self-reflection. Give your mind and heart a break from the chaos of everyday life. Deeply examine and empty your self to find absolute peace and freedom.

We are located at 475 Cedar Lane Teaneck, NJ 07666. Our meditation center is located next to Veggie Heaven. Parking is in the front, and additional parking is located in the back of the shopping strip. This introduction will last about an hour.

The Braveheart Men’s choir will be celebrating & challenging masculinity through song. The choir is half gay and half straight... so the only thing we can be certain of is that this show will have a lot of balls! 

The choir consists of musicians, Shakespearean and musical actors, broadway lovers, and total newbs. We all love to sing, dance and be merry.

The cabaret is a product of the Braveheart Men’s Movement, an inclusive community committed to breaking down barriers that divide men through the practice of courageous self expression.

Proceeds will be donated to SCHAP Community School in Matoso, Kenya. 

The Duplex is a relatively small space so if you know you want to see the magic live, get your ticket now through the link below: 

https://www.purplepass.com/butch

We'll see you there!
Love,
Michael, Eduardo, Zachary, Jason, Mark, Alan, Garrett

results.description:
Date Walking is kind of like speed dating except not as awkward, not as frantic and a heck of a lot more relaxed. When you come to a Date Walking event, you will take a casual stroll with anywhere from 5 to 15 wo/men over the course of an hour or two. Once you've met everyone, we usually get food and/or drinks somewhere. It's a really fun and relaxed way to meet someone special or multiple possibilities face-to-face.

Dear people who do not like walking in sub-zero temperatures, 

The Winter Garden is a spectacular 3-story barrel-vaulted glass atrium, offering panoramic views of the World Trade Center and Lower Manhattan at one end, and showcasing a majestic bay window with magnificent views of the Hudson River on the other. The central feature of the Winter Garden is the grand semicircular staircase, fashioned of Italian marble, which opens to a grove of 45-foot palm trees. Let me tell you, this place is amazing! It's perfect for Date Walking in the winter and/or on rainy days too, so you can say goodbye to Central Park Singles Strolls for now. I'll bring them back when the weather gets warmer.  

Check out some photos from one of last Winter's events at this venue here. 

The exact meeting spot is where the 40’ palm trees are. You can’t miss it. Look for the tallest guy there. That will be Beau, your Date Walking Organizer, or you can call me at[masked] and I'll wave you over to where we're at.

The meeting time is 4:30 PM and we will wait 20 minutes for everyone to arrive. 


After our Date Walk, upstairs is an AMAZING food court called Hudson Eats with so many options it will make your head spin + there's TONS of seating and SPECTACULAR views of the Hudson River!! They also serve wine and beer up there so like OMG it's going to be AWESOME!! Trust me. Oh and the Museum of Feelings is just outside, so we can check that out too. 

If this is your first time doing a Date Walk have no fear. It's like the easiest and least awkward way to meet people. You just walk and talk. 

When you come to the event pay $10 and I will provide you with a ticket that’s good for 30-days. Hold onto the ticket and come to any/all Date Walking events for 30 days. Just show your ticket and you're good to go. 

Why am I paying you a fee for a place I can go to for free? See the answer here. 

If you have any questions prior to or on the day of the event, please do not hesitate to give me a call or text at [masked]

Thank you, 
Beau, your Date Walking Organizer 
  Call/Text:[masked] 
Email: [masked] 
Date Walking | Facebook | Twitter 

Please be aware that while an equal number of men and women is preferred it is not always the case.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet under the 40' palm trees or call 347-225-3516
results.name: Date Walking in The Winter Garden Atrium - Age: 21 to 49

group.name: Date Walking - The Easiest Way to Meet Someone Special

results.description:
A Conversation About Happiness

Alternating Hosts: George & Michael Y.   Guest Host this Saturday: Yen

</a> CitiCorp Atrium Lower Level
153 E 53rd street (Between Lexington and 3rd ave)

Look for our red Meetup Sign.

Get ready to get happier simply by talking about happiness! The theory behind these events comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group. It's important that our events be fun! So with that in mind, let's get serious about ramping up our enjoyment of life!

(photo of atrium and location of meetup table)

(photo of atrium entrance at the corner of 53rd and Lex.)


At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps (see photo) leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.

Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

<a href="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.335.9655&rep=rep1&type=pdf">Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages
results.how_to_find_us: At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.
results.name: A Conversation About Happiness, Citicorp at 53rd and Lex. Guest Host: Yen

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group. It's important that our events be fun! So with that in mind, let's get serious about ramping up our enjoyment of life!

At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps (see photo) leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.

Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change 
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005. 21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions 
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress 
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages"

********************

About this week's moderator:  Yen is a parent and is currently trading at  $[masked] US, haha.
results.name: "A Conversation About Happiness" Guest Host - Yen

results.description:
Welcome!

If you love to play basketball, but height is not your advantage, come out and play with people who aren't excessively tall! In the tradition of Spud Webb, anyone under 5'8", male or female, is welcome to join us on the court. We'll get some teams together and play some competitive, but relaxed bball-- and without any giant hands in our faces! :-p

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we must be out of the gym no later than 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

Don't forget:


* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* To be eligible to play we ask that you sign an annual waiver, which can be found here.


* If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers a message. 

The Rules:

1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds. 

6. Usually each team has 1-2 subs. Subs should enter mid-game (one of the teams reaches 6 points) and should start the following game. Teams can regulate themselves but let's just make sure everyone plays!

See you on the court! B-)

***SPECIAL NOTES***

Please do not show up unannounced (without RSVP):

This gym is small and 22 is the maximum number of players we can realistically allow. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. If you do show up unannounced we will have to ask you to leave. 

Refund Policy:

A refund/credit is available if you change your RSVP at least 24 hours in advance OR, if you change your RSVP within 24 hours, as long as you post a comment on the event page and someone picks up your spot (BOTH are required).

Lastly...

Feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your fingernails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.

The Afterparty: 

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later!
results.name: Indoor bball warm up & pickup games

Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
